meanings.definition: To mix up or distort information
meanings.sent1: She kept garbling the instructions, making it hard to follow.
meanings.sent2: Please don't garble the message when you pass it along.
meanings.sent3: The parrot started garbling the song lyrics, creating a funny melody.
meanings.sent4: His tired mind began garbling reality, turning the world into a surreal dream.
meanings.sent5: The static on the radio garbled the broadcast, leaving only fragments of words.

meanings.definition: To confuse or jumble words or phrases
meanings.sent1: The toddler tends to garble her words when she's excited.
meanings.sent2: When nervous, he tends to garble his speech and mix up his sentences.
meanings.sent3: The comedian intentionally garbled his punchline, creating a hilarious mix-up.
meanings.sent4: The strong accent garbled the pronunciation, making it hard to understand.
meanings.sent5: The faulty microphone garbled his voice, distorting his message.

meanings.definition: The act of altering or misrepresenting information
meanings.sent1: The garbling of facts led to a misunderstanding among the group.
meanings.sent2: His constant garbling of the truth made it hard to trust his words.
meanings.sent3: The spy's garbling of the documents caused chaos in the agency.
meanings.sent4: The garbling of history in the book raised questions about its accuracy.
meanings.sent5: The deliberate garbling of evidence pointed towards a cover-up.
